lead_paragraph: The de Blasio administration has claimed for months that top officials knew nothing about deed restrictions lifted on a nursing home, but documents obtained by The New York Times indicate otherwise.

headline.print_headline: Memos Imply That City Hall Knew of Nursing Home Deal
headline.main: Memos Imply That City Hall Knew of Nursing Home Deal

snippet: The de Blasio administration has claimed for months that top officials knew nothing about deed restrictions lifted on a nursing home, but documents obtained by The New York Times indicate otherwise.
abstract: Memos obtained by The New York Times suggest Anthony Shorris, Mayor Bill de Blasio's first deputy mayor, was aware midway through 2015 of lifting of deed restrictions on Rivington House, former nursing home, allowing it to be sold to luxury condominium developer Allure Group for $116 million; de Blasio administration officials have said Shorris was unaware of lifting of deed until after building was sold.
